Myldred Boston Howell

  1. Home

  2. Explore Stories

  3. Biography

Myldred Howell

Themes

Trailblazers
Social Justice & Activism
Racism & Resistance

Biography

When Myldred Boston sent out letters to multiple schools requesting information, Miami University was one of the first schools to reply. After visiting campus she was excited to start her education. When Myldred entered Miami University in 1945 she was the first in her family to attend college. She graduated in 1949 with a Bachelor of Arts in Sociology. Myldred was a great driving force for needed change, on campus and off. Through her bravery and refusal to accept unacceptable treatment, Myldred used her voice to instill change.

Myldred was one of the first two female African American students to live on campus. When Myldred arrived on Move in Day in 1945, she was very disappointed. The room she was assigned was not only in appalling conditions, it was in the basement, next to the furnace room. In a 2006 interview Myldred recalled, “ that wasn’t going to be where I would be living,”. Myldred invited the Dean of Women to see the dorm room herself. When she arrived, Myldred asked the Dean if she would live there, her response was no and Myldred said “and so was mine.” For the rest of her first year, Myldred lived with Mr. and Mrs. Jackson, an African American family living on Vine Street in Oxford. At the time many African American students lived with local African American families so they could attend the university.

Her sophomore year, Myldred lived at the Tallawanda Apartments. The transition back onto campus would prove to create new challenges for Myldred. Miami University reached out to the parents of the other students living at the Tallawanda Apartments to ask them if they knew an African American woman would be living on the first floor. All of the students living on the first floor with Myldred were women whose parents consented. Myldred recounted that she had met the women who would become her roommates in class and they got along. Myldred’s dorm included herself and five other women. The Tallawanda Apartment building housed two hundred women across three floors. Myldred proved that the dorms could successfully integrate.

On campus and uptown proved to be problematic for the African American community. Myldred recalled, “The people in the town who wanted to buy sandwiches would be served from the rear of that establishment,” she said. “You’d have to go to the back of the establishment and get your brown paper bag … and I just couldn’t do that.”. The racial discrimination Myldred experienced inspired her to join the Campus Interracial Club where she held the position of corresponding secretary. The club did not feel welcomed on campus so instead the students sought off campus options for club meetings and social events. Myldred shared that, “the people in the town opened their homes to us so I have a strong affinity for them”. The Campus Interracial Club provided a social space for African American students to get the support they needed and feel heard. During Myldred’s time as a student, she saw change in the uptown restaurants. Myldred said, “Those who were serving us at first didn’t serve us,” she said. “But we sat and sat, and we changed positions and others would come and sit, and all of a sudden at some point in time, we could walk in and be seated and were served.”

After graduating from Miami University in 1949, Myldred completed a Masters of Library and Information Science from Case Western Reserve University in 1957. For ten years, Myldred taught elementary school in Cleveland, Ohio. She shifted careers when she started working in real estate sales in 1961. She continued in this field, eventually becoming the owner of her own reality company. In the 1980’s Myldred’s daughter attended Miami University, studying language and joining the Black Student Action Association. Myldred has visited Miami University multiple times during her life and has especially enjoyed visiting the homes of the families who welcomed her and The Campus Interracial Club during her years as a Miami student. In 2005 the Pioneer Award was established to recognize those who have broken new ground and prepared the way for other African American Students. Myldred Boston Howell exemplified these accomplishments through her tenacity and determination to receive fair treatment. She is a role model, showing those who hear her story that no one should accept improper treatment.

Credits

Written by Laura Janosik, (4, History, 2023)
